text: I believe Bonjour and welcome to
Mauritius
[Music]
we will be spending the next seven days
in this beautiful island nation of the
eastern coast of Africa and it's not
only me who says it's beautiful the
great Mark Twain once wrote heaven was
copied after Mauritius but putting the
natural beauty aside waterfall this
island has a lot to offer from big-city
life to markets walking through the
market here in for the week two
submarines two street food I don't know
why don't have to eat but it looks
really good to smiling faces and luxury
hotels like Solana Beach right it's kind
of a one-stop shop with so many stories
to tell I'm going to assume that most of
you don't know much about this volcanic
country which is currently celebrating
50 years of independence from the
British I surely didn't know much about
Mauritius just a few days ago but after
meeting some locals who have taken me
around and helped me understand their
lifestyle my interest has piqued here
are five things you didn't know about
Mauritius one no indigenous population
Mauritius has been influenced and
settled by several world powers like the
French East African the British and the
Indian as a result the 1.3 million
locals are multi-ethnic multi-religious
and multilingual who all live together
on an island that's just 28 miles wide
by 40 miles long it's the most densely
populated country in Africa - their
language is Creole almost everyone
speaks three languages fluently English
French and Creole with the latter being
spoken 85% of the time well Creole is
the language which was invented by
sleeves
Indians etc trying to speak French
because most people were working for the
French
there's a word that you need to know
when you speak Creole it's ru ru it's
something we use for everything you
could say are you faster it's hot 3
Hinduism Mauritius is the only African
country that has Hinduism as the main
religion I'm here at one of the Hindu
temples in Mauritius as you wander
around the island from big cities to
rural villages you can see colorful
Hindu temples that take me right back to
my days in India for its remote
Mauritius lies about a thousand
kilometres east of Madagascar and 4000
kilometers south of India in the middle
of the Indian Ocean its isolation has
led to a unique lifestyle language and
cuisine that can quickly be noticed as
you roam around the island especially in
the food
here it's spring onions coriander and
chili fries in sunflower oil 5 it has
transformed since its independence from
Great Britain in 1968 Mauritius has gone
from a low-income agriculture-based
economy to a more stable and wealthier
one fuelled by tourism technology and
the exports of sugarcane textile and
fish the financial district of Port
Louis is booming
our journey around Mauritius will
continue for the next week and I can't
wait to see what more we will discover
I'm Drew Pinsky and if you like my
travel videos please click Subscribe and
join me as I plan to visit every country
in the world
